it) and drew his attention to the verses. 
"Well, I will read them, then!" Bagrati6n seemed to say, and, fixing his weary eyes on the paper, began to read them with a fixed and serious expression. But the author himself took the verses and began reading them aloud. Ba- grati6n bowed his head and listened: 
Bring glory then to Alexander's reign 
And on the throne our Titus shield. 
A dreaded foe be thou, kindhearted as a man, 
A Rhipheus at home, a Caesar in the field! 
E'en fortunate Napoleon
